awd_abstract_narration:
The low numbers of computer science graduates is a national concern. One of the frequently cited reasons for leaving computer science is students' difficulties with programming. The goal of this project is to build a software tutor that provides feedback designed to guide students through the process of developing a sequence of steps to solve a given problem, selecting the programming language features appropriate for each step, and then writing code using those features. Students will learn to solve 40 different problems of varying complexity using the software tutor. The software tutor is expected to help reduce the number of students, especially women, who typically drop out of programming courses and increase the number of graduates who eventually go on to careers in Information Technology. 

This research and development project will consist of the following activities: 1) Creation of practice software that provides formative feedback to help students learn algorithm formulation and program design by solving problems. In addition, students will learn to write code for the problems, which will cover selection, loops, and functions in both Java and C++. 2) Assessment of student learning throughout the course using a formative evaluation of the pedagogic modules and feedback from the practice software. Summative evaluation will examine the impact of the software on the success of students in an introductory Computer Science course, measured in terms of grades, retention, and specifically, the differential impact of the software on women in the introductory programming course. 3) Dissemination of the results of the project through research conferences and journals and by sharing the practice software among educators so it can be adopted and used in other introductory Computer Science courses.

por.por_cntn:
Writing a computer program to solve a problem involves three steps: designing an algorithm for the problem, designing a program for the algorithm and writing the program code. We developed a software tutor that helps a student work through all these steps by asking the right questions in the right sequence. At each step, the tutor provides immediate feedback to guide the student towards the correct answer. So, with the aid of the tutor, the student is guaranteed to write a complete and correct program for each problem. The tutor also enforces good programming practices. It can be used to write programs in C++ and Java, two of the more popular programing languages.

The tutor is so designed that new problems can be added to it with minimal effort; the pedagogy used by it can be similarly easily modified; and what students see when using the tutor is what they encounter in real life when writing programs. These features set it apart from the programming tutors developed by Intelligent Tutoring Systems researchers over the last four decades.

The tutor makes it possible for students to write several programs from start to finish each week with the assistance of one-on-one tutoring. Such increased practice leads to better outcomes in programming courses. In our evaluations, we found that practicing with the tutor helped students write programs faster and with fewer mistakes. We also found that students who had practiced with the tutor scored higher in subsequent online tests. So, using the tutor improves the preparedness of programming students and thereby, the quality of computing graduates.  

By reducing solving problems to a well-defined sequence of steps, the tutor facilitates computational thinking, one of the fundamental skills of the 21st century. So, the tutor can be used to improve the computational thinking skills of non-programming students. It does so in the context of textual programming, a real-life skill, which sets the tutor apart from other extant approaches for promoting computational thinking. The tutor is set up to be used online, anytime, anywhere, and as often as needed for mastery learning.

In addition to the development of the tutor, numerous studies were conducted in this project on the features of intellilgent tutors and their effectiveness. These studies resulted in over two dozen publications in peer-reviewed conferences.
